definition: The measure of actual liquidity supplied to the market, calculated by subtracting the Treasury General Account (TGA) and Reverse Repo (RRP) balances from the Fed's Balance Sheet.

market_impact.up: Price appreciation in risk assets (stocks, crypto). Creates an environment tolerant of PER expansion.
market_impact.down: Increased market volatility. Valuation adjustments likely, especially in growth stocks.

context_2026: In 2026, with the end of QT and adjustments to Digital Fiat Currency (CBDC) reserves, qualitative changes in quantitative policy are in focus. The fluctuation of this real liquidity determines market resilience more than simple interest rates.
gms_relevance: Extremely High. Forms the baseline of the GMS Score and functions as a fundamental variable measuring the market's 'buying power'.

definition: A measure of expected 30-day volatility based on S&P 500 option prices. Quantifies investor psychological anxiety.

market_impact.up: Investor risk-off. Rapid spikes signal panic selling, but extreme highs can suggest a buying opportunity (selling climax).
market_impact.down: Investor optimism. Stable levels encourage carry trades and leveraged investment.

context_2026: With AI-driven ultra-high-speed algorithmic trading now mainstream, VIX spikes tend to be short-lived ('spike transience'). Also heavily influenced by Zero-Day Options (0DTE).
gms_relevance: High. Used as an inverse correlation indicator to detect reversals in risk tolerance. Algorithms significantly lower the score when above 20.

definition: Nominal interest rate (e.g., 10Y Yield) minus expected inflation rate. The true cost of borrowing money.

market_impact.up: Headwind for Gold, Bitcoin, and high-PER tech stocks. Factor for a stronger Dollar.
market_impact.down: Boosts asset prices. Accelerates risk money inflow into AI startups and other sectors.

context_2026: AI-driven boosts to potential growth rates have raised the neutral real interest rate (r-star). Understanding the 'New Normal' of stock rallies amidst positive real interest rates is key in 2026.
gms_relevance: High. Functions as the discount rate. A primary weighting factor measuring valuation appropriateness in the GMS Score.

definition: A comprehensive market leading indicator calculated proprietarily by OmniMetric, integrating liquidity, fundamentals, SNS sentiment, and AI demand forecasts.

market_impact.up: Improvement in overall market expected value. Increased advantage for trend-following strategies.
market_impact.down: Warning of potential pullback risk. Recommends hedging or increasing cash ratios.

context_2026: Utilizing the latest LLM engines (including Gemini 3) in 2026. A next-gen compass synchronizing qualitative SNS info with economic stats in real-time to eliminate information asymmetry.
gms_relevance: Core Indicator. All other items are positioned as components to construct this score.

definition: Measures price changes in goods and services purchased by consumers. Has the most direct impact on central bank monetary policy.

market_impact.up: Stock declines and Dollar strength due to rate hike/tightening fears. Risk of reflation.
market_impact.down: Stock rallies and Dollar weakness on rate cut hopes. Progress in disinflation is welcomed.

context_2026: In 2026, attention is on the expanding contribution of new service sectors like 'AI Agent Subscription Costs' and 'Robotaxi Fares', rather than energy prices.
gms_relevance: Medium. Becoming a lagging indicator, so weighted lower in the GMS Score than leading indicators like PCE or employment data.

definition: The Fed's preferred inflation metric. Reflects changes in consumer spending patterns and covers a broader range of price movements than CPI.

market_impact.up: Strengthens Fed hawkishness, leading to higher terminal rates. Weighs on tech stocks.
market_impact.down: Raises hopes for a Fed dovish pivot, giving general market relief.

context_2026: Decreasing rent ratios and deflationary pressure in 'intangible asset services' due to AI productivity gains contribute to PCE stability. Holds the key to the Fed achieving its 2% target.
gms_relevance: High. Adopted as higher-precision input data than CPI for predicting policy rate changes.

definition: The most important monthly indicator of US economic health. Labor market strength underpins consumption.

market_impact.up: Proof of a strong economy, but overheating can lead to temporary stock declines due to rate hike fears (Good is Bad).
market_impact.down: Stock declines due to slowdown/recession fears, or rallies on early rate cut hopes.

context_2026: AI adoption has intensified labor mobility. 'White-collar re-employment rates' and 'Wage growth for AI-skilled workers' now influence market reactions more than simple employment numbers.
gms_relevance: High. The engine measuring economic health. Directly linked to GMS Score recession risk assessment.

definition: A phenomenon where the 10-year Treasury yield falls below the 2-year yield. Historically a leading indicator of recession.

market_impact.up: (Steepening) Expectations of economic recovery, or reflation. Positive for financial stocks.
market_impact.down: (Flattening/Deepening Inversion) Sign of recession. Medium to long-term risk-off.

context_2026: After resolving a long-standing inversion (steepening), 2026 stands at a crossroads: has the economy returned to cruising speed, or is it falling into stagflation?
gms_relevance: Medium. Due to structural changes in bond supply/demand, its predictive accuracy has waned, so it's evaluated in combination with other indicators.

definition: The US policy interest rate. The source of all interest rates, governing global capital flows.

market_impact.up: Stronger Dollar, lower asset prices, increased corporate debt burden.
market_impact.down: Weaker Dollar, risk-on markets, vitalization of the housing market.

context_2026: With the rise of the neutral rate (r-star), a return to the zero-interest era of the 2010s is not expected. Revenue models that work in a 'world with interest' (maintained at 3-4%) are required.
gms_relevance: Extremely High. Direct input for discount rate. Affects 'Leverage Recommendation' in the GMS Score.

definition: A next-gen leading economic indicator integrating data center capex, GPU lead times, and LLM token consumption.

market_impact.up: Strong buy signal for semiconductor, energy, and tech sectors. Expansion of capex.
market_impact.down: Fears of AI bubble burst. Suggests lower capital efficiency due to over-investment.

context_2026: AI is no longer just a sector story but a macro variable defining productivity across all industries. A decline in this index foreshadows a drop in GDP growth quarters later.
gms_relevance: High. Valued in the 2026 GMS Score as a 'New Leading Indicator' replacing the traditional ISM Manufacturing PMI.

definition: Semiconductor maker Book-to-Bill ratio. Reflects the demand cycle from IT devices to AI servers and EVs.

market_impact.up: Bottoming out is a prime buying opportunity for tech stocks. Peaking suggests profit-taking time.
market_impact.down: Turning point from over-demand to over-supply. Early sign of economic slowdown.

context_2026: The spread of Edge AI (AI processing on phones/PCs) has shortened and intensified the cycle. 2026 marks the end of inventory correction for general chips and a transition to next-gen standards.
gms_relevance: Medium. Used for Sector Rotation prediction in the GMS Score.

definition: Circulation and usage rate of digital currencies issued by major central banks. Measures settlement speed and currency programmability.

market_impact.up: Faster capital circulation. Improved transmission speed of monetary policy. Threat to existing banking sector.
market_impact.down: Credit concerns due to privacy issues or system failures. Lower trust in fiat (flight to Gold/BTC).

context_2026: In 2026, major central banks begin full CBDC operations. This enables direct distribution of 'Helicopter Money', noting increased difficulty in inflation control.
gms_relevance: Medium. Incorporated into GMS Score as a variable for Money Velocity.

definition: Expected volatility of the US Treasury market calculated from bond options.

market_impact.up: Increased uncertainty in rate outlook. Negative for mortgages and corporate bond markets. Volatile Dollar.
market_impact.down: Stable rates encourage capital inflow to risk assets. Activation of carry trades.

context_2026: With Fed forward guidance shifting to an AI-driven interactive model, calmness in this index is an essential condition for market stability.
gms_relevance: Medium. Used in combination with VIX for multi-asset risk assessment.

definition: Quantifies market enthusiasm (0-100) from multiple data points like stock momentum, volatility, and junk bond demand.

market_impact.up: (Greed) Bull market, but over 80 indicates high risk of pullback due to overheating.
market_impact.down: (Fear) Bear market, but under 20 suggests a technical rebound due to overselling is near.

context_2026: Algorithmic contrarian trading has become common, making recovery from Extreme Fear extremely fast. A mandatory indicator for short-term swing trading.
gms_relevance: Medium. Contributes as a 'Contrarian Momentum' component in the GMS Score.

definition: Copper price divided by Gold price. Ascends during expansion, declines during recession. A leading economic indicator.

market_impact.up: Revitalization of global manufacturing and infrastructure investment. Risk-on.
market_impact.down: Shift to defensive assets (Gold). Stagnation or rising geopolitical risk.

context_2026: Structural copper shortages are evident due to the transition to a decarbonized/electrified society (AI Data Centers/EVs). More of an 'Energy Transition Progress Index' than a simple economic indicator now.
gms_relevance: Medium. Alternative indicator measuring the 'thermal energy' of the real economy.

definition: Total supply of currency including cash, deposits, and MMFs. Long-term driver of inflation and asset prices.

market_impact.up: Medium/Long-term inflation pressure. Currency depreciation (weaker Dollar) and asset inflation.
market_impact.down: Deflationary pressure. Contraction of economic activity. Formation of stock market top.

context_2026: Note that money is moving from bank deposits to on-chain assets (stablecoins), so traditional M2 stats alone no longer capture the full liquidity picture.
gms_relevance: Medium. Supplementary data for liquidity analysis. Checked for divergence from Net Liquidity.

definition: Survey of purchasing managers in the US manufacturing sector. Above 50 indicates expansion, below 50 contraction.

market_impact.up: Manufacturing revival, expectations of profit growth. Tailwind for value stocks.
market_impact.down: Manufacturing decline, recession fears. Shift to defensive stocks.

context_2026: Automation via 'Smart Factories' implies 'New Orders' and 'Input Prices (AI Energy Costs)' are gaining importance over employment components.
gms_relevance: Medium. Used as a 'Confirmation Indicator' to verify traditional business cycles.

definition: Yield difference between US Treasuries and other sovereign bonds (or corporate bonds). Sensitivity to market credit risk.

market_impact.up: (Widening) Risk-off. Capital flight from emerging markets or corporate default fears.
market_impact.down: (Narrowing) Risk-on. Improved global investment appetite. Inflow to high-yield assets.

context_2026: With more nations holding massive debt, CDS (Credit Default Swaps) on US Treasuries themselves have become a new key indicator measuring eligibility as risk-free assets.
gms_relevance: Medium. Captures signs of systemic risk and calculates downside risk for the GMS Score.

definition: Calculates the growth in GDP contribution per unit hour due to AI adoption. Used to correct potential growth rates.

market_impact.up: Economic growth without inflation. Enables sustained stock rallies even under high real interest rates.
market_impact.down: Slowing returns on AI investment. Stagflation fears due to stalled productivity gains.

context_2026: In 2026, over 30% of all industries are autonomous via AI Agents. This multiplier is a leading indicator predicting future corporate profit margins.
gms_relevance: High. Maximum rating in the GMS Score 'Growth' category as a factor raising the long-term market ceiling.

definition: Balance of excess funds deposited by MMFs and others at the Fed. A buffer of 'standby funds' that can flow back into the market.

market_impact.up: Absorption of liquidity from the market. Neutral to negative for stocks.
market_impact.down: Release of liquidity to the market. Strong support factor for risk assets (liquidity supply).

context_2026: How the RRP balance, which plummeted from 2024-2025, moves under the new 2026 regulatory environment determines market tail risk.
gms_relevance: High. Essential variable for calculating Net Liquidity. Low balances indicate reduced market resilience.

definition: The yield on 10-year US government bonds. It is the cornerstone of global financial markets and the benchmark for all borrowing costs.

market_impact.up: Higher borrowing costs for companies and consumers. Pressures equity valuations, especially in the tech sector.
market_impact.down: Lower interest burden and stimulating effect on the economy. Tailwind for equities and long-duration assets.

context_2026: Serves as the global discount rate anchor. In 2026, the 'term premium' has returned to positive territory, making yield levels above 4.5% a critical threshold for risk assets.
gms_relevance: Extremely High. A primary variable in the GMS Score measuring risk-free rate stress.

definition: The market's expectation of average annual inflation over the next 10 years, derived from the difference between nominal and tips yields.

market_impact.up: Signals inflationary pressure. Suggests a hawkish Fed policy path. Good for commodities, bad for growth stocks.
market_impact.down: Signals disinflationary trends. Allows for a more dovish Fed. Positive for bond prices and growth assets.

context_2026: Monitors the stability of long-term inflation expectations. Vital for verifying if central banks have achieved a 'soft landing' in an AI-automated economy.
gms_relevance: High. Used to calculate real rates and assess the 'Inflation Regime' component of the score.

definition: A measure of the value of the U.S. dollar relative to a basket of foreign currencies from U.S. trade partners.

market_impact.up: Usually signals global liquidity stress and risk-off sentiment. Negative for emerging markets and commodities.
market_impact.down: Signals ample dollar liquidity and risk-on sentiment. Boosts global trade and multi-national company earnings.

context_2026: The 'Dollar Smile' theory remains dominant. In the 2026 macro environment, DXY acts as a 'Safety Valve' for the global financial machine.
gms_relevance: High. Functions as a proxy for 'Global Liquidity Stress' in the multi-asset matrix.

definition: A stock market index tracking the stock performance of 500 of the largest companies listed on stock exchanges in the United States.

market_impact.up: Representative of broad economic optimism and risk appetite.
market_impact.down: Reflects earnings contraction, recession fears, or systemic risk.

context_2026: The index is increasingly dominated by AI-integrated giants. The 'Magnificent AI' era has redefined traditional P/E ratio norms.
gms_relevance: Target Benchmark. The GMS Score aims to predict the leading and trailing edges of this index's movements.

definition: The ratio between the Equal-weighted S&P 500 and the Market-cap weighted S&P 500. It measures the health and participation level of a rally.

market_impact.up: Broad-based participation. Indicates a healthy, sustainable bull market across multiple sectors.
market_impact.down: Narrow leadership (usually just a few tech giants). Signals potential fragility in the overall index level.

context_2026: Identifying whether the AI rally is 'broadening out' to mid-caps and industrial sectors is the primary alpha-driver in 2026.
gms_relevance: Medium. Used to detect 'Quality and Participation' shifts that simple index prices hide.

definition: An industrial base metal that is often seen as a proxy for global economic health due to its widespread use in manufacturing and construction.

market_impact.up: Signs of robust global industrial activity. Positive for growth-oriented sectors.
market_impact.down: Signals potential slowdown in global CAPEX and manufacturing. Precursor to economic weakness.

context_2026: With the massive expansion of AI data centers and electrification, Copper is now the 'Oil of the Digital Age'.
gms_relevance: Medium. Functions as a 'Real Economy Thermal Energy' indicator in the Commodities stack.

definition: The ultimate safe-haven asset and a store of value. It serves as a hedge against inflation and currency debasement.

market_impact.up: Signals fear, high inflation, or weakening of paper currencies. Negative for real rates.
market_impact.down: Risk-on appetite. Signals confidence in the financial system and rising real yields.

context_2026: Gold remains the 'Anti-Dollar'. In a world of ballooning sovereign debt, Central Bank gold purchases are at record highs in 2026.
gms_relevance: Medium. Used as an 'Insurance Variable' to measure the systemic trust level in the GMS model.

definition: The first decentralized cryptocurrency. Often referred to as 'Digital Gold' and a leading indicator for high-beta risk sentiment.

market_impact.up: Maximum risk-on appetite. Reflects ample liquidity and speculative demand.
market_impact.down: Deleveraging phase. Signals a pull-back in speculative liquidity and rising risk aversion.

context_2026: Institutional adoption via ETFs is complete. BTC is now a permanent fixture in global macro asset allocation models.
gms_relevance: High. Functions as a 'Liquidity Thermometer'. BTC price sensitivity to Net Liquidity changes is a key signal.

definition: A decentralized, open-source blockchain with smart contract functionality. Acts as a proxy for the 'Internet of Finance'.

market_impact.up: Expansion of on-chain activity and decentralized liquidity.
market_impact.down: Contraction of the decentralized economy and higher gas fees / network bottlenecks.

context_2026: ETH is the infrastructure layer for 'Programmable Money'. In 2026, its correlation with AI agent computing demand is increasing.
gms_relevance: Medium. Measures the 'Utility Side' of the crypto liquidity cycle.

definition: A benchmark for global energy prices. Reflects global growth expectations and geopolitical risk premiums.

market_impact.up: Economic expansion demand, or supply shocks. High oil prices can be inflationary 'tax' on consumers.
market_impact.down: Demand destruction or oversupply. Usually associated with economic slowdowns.

context_2026: The tug-of-war continues between AI-driven energy demand and the transition to renewables. Efficient energy production is the 2026 growth governor.
gms_relevance: Medium. A key variable in the 'Energy and Growth' component of the GMS model.

definition: OmniMetric's strategic selection of 16 multi-asset indicators designed to capture the interplay of Rates, Liquidity, Risk, and the Real Economy.

market_impact.up: A holistic view of the global financial system.
market_impact.down: Avoids 'Information Blind Spots' common in single-asset analysis.

context_2026: In a hypersensitive market, looking at one indicator is dangerous. We synchronize all 16 dots into a single GMS narrative.
gms_relevance: Foundational. Explains why our dashboard is structured as a 4x4 'Control Tower'.
